page.title: 07WILDLIFE IN THE NORTH TYNE
page.content: The Roe Deer graze freely on both sides of the river from Redesmouth to Lea Hall, badgers, foxes and a newcomer the mink are also there. The {woodland}hides stoats, squirrels and weasels. On the water edge live rats, frogs, toads, salmon, trout and eels.In the fields ther are moles, rabbits, hedgehogs and field mice. On {higher ground}hares are seen and on sunny days the adder may be found. A range of birds inhabit the area with the heronry near Lea Hall of note.{By} {the water}live ducks, wagtails and dippers. In the woods are owls, wood pigeon, wood pecker, rooks, magpie, pheasant, sparrowhawk and grouse also the summer migrant the cuckoo.{In the} {hedgerow}blackbirds, thrush, chaffinch, tits, yellowhammer and in the open the skylark, snipe, curlew,and lapwing.
